texts.definition: Routes that focus and guide movement in a game.
markups: <style="Definition">Routes that focus and guide movement in a game.</style>

Movement in games often provide players with choices of where to move. <style="CurrentLink">Laning</style> occurs when players and other agents in a game need to, or are strongly encourage to, move in a pre-set limited number of routes than make gameplay more predictable.

<style="CurrentLink">Laning</style> as a concept was developed in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:%20Multiplayer%20Online%20Battle%20Arena%20Games">MOBA Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Defense%20of%20the%20Ancients">Defense of the Ancients</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/League%20of%20Legends">League of Legends</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Laning</style> is a way of restricting <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> in games, especially in the designs of <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style>, which primarily tends to affect a game's <style="Link"><link="startgame">Startgame</link></style>. The typical use of <style="CurrentLink">Laning</style> assumes movement from both direction from opposed forces which, with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Multiplayer%20Online%20Battle%20Arena%20Games">MOBA Games</link></style> as the originating example, which modifies how <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> need to be considered and may motivate the use of <style="Link"><link="scouting">Scouting</link></style>. Designing for <style="CurrentLink">Laning</style> in a game consists of making several routes to one area, in practice by either making several routes that are <style="Link"><link="transport-routes">Transport Routes</link></style> between the same areas or making several routes that are <style="Link"><link="flanking-routes">Flanking Routes</link></style> to each other. The design of <style="CurrentLink">Laning</style> is heavily influenced by the presence of <style="Link"><link="bases">Bases</link></style> at the beginning and end of lanes as well as if the lanes are the only ways to move between them (i.e. the design can be influenced by <style="Link"><link="inaccessible-areas">Inaccessible Areas</link></style>).

While <style="CurrentLink">Laning</style> can be considered without use of <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style>, the pattern is very often used to not only provide various routes for the <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> controlled by players but also for <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> (under the players' control or not). Likewise, the lanes may the only or normal routes to use for some game elements (typically <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style>) while others (typically <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style>) may take other routes although these may be slower or contain challenges.

The existence of <style="CurrentLink">Laning</style> typically creates <style="Link"><link="choke-points">Choke Points</link></style>, either in the lanes themselves or where they end. How players act upon the designs of <style="CurrentLink">Laning</style> typically constitutes the <style="Link"><link="startgame">Startgame</link></style> phase of a game instance. How to handle the choices presented in games with <style="CurrentLink">Laning</style> motivate both <style="Link"><link="tactical-planning">Tactical</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="strategic-planning">Strategic Planning</link></style>.
